I use Xbox one for with this headset and the sound is not as good as other headsets I usually use but this one has more useful features than others like it has a lift up to mute microphone, or bendable ear pads if your not using them.

The lineup of Logitech "G" series headsets is a little confusing, in terms of price and capability, since the numbers don't necessarily correspond to either.
Having recently evaluated some of the Logitech "G" series headsets higher in the range, I was curious to see what the G432 would bring at its lower price point.
By number, the G432 would appear to be sitting the low to midrange of the products, and is seemingly just a G332 with DTS Headphone X 2.0.
My comfort is firmly rooted in the ergonomic factors that feed into wearing the headset for up to a couple hours (I'm not really hardcore enough to ever wear them longer than that).
I was expecting a decent performance from the 50mm drivers in the G432, and they were only just okay.
I own Logitech keyboard, mouse, and now headset.
I enjoyed the movement of the volume wheel and microphone mute being placed into the headset compared to being on the cable.
The downside to this product was the absence of a braided cable compared to my last headset, and it's previous generation.
Not to disrespect this headset too much.
But after wearing it for hour straight ears may get sore so take breaks.
Used for gaming.
The only complaint I have would be the usb extension is short.
I'm aware headsets dont last forever however bit by bit this head broke down before being scrapped.

This headset for its price is amazing.

I dont like having the volume and mic mute placed on the headset as you have to move your hands farther away from the keyboard in order to use them.
Overall Im less impressed with the G432.

Also the G432 seems tighter on my head than the G430 so these will more than likely have the same issue breaking at the earpiece-headband junction like all other headsets of this design (swiveling earpieces aka DJ-style)  The connection is also different than the G430 which some might consider an improvement.

but other than that I love this headset and would buy it again

headphone.review: He is really enthusiastic about these headphones.

He said that most of his friends have wireless headphones, but more often than not, the kids can't use their headphones because they forget to charge them.

logitech.review: * Cord length and jack.
The Logitech cans are more full without that treble focus, you might even call them a bit muddy.

As for me, the difficulty to get it to work on my laptop is indeed a very big con and I do consider it unacceptable.
One of my favorites being the Logitech G433 7.1 because of its simplicity, comfort, price and amazing 7.1 results.
I will preface my review by stating that I own and have reviewed many many headphones on Amazon, including many gaming headsets, notably Logitech ones.
Cord had loose connection, making it come out sometimes...and required it to be turned at a certain angle.
G Hub software is garbage.
They finally gave out a few days ago and I bought these since I own quite a few logitech devices and all have been good.
One Disclaimer is that you NEED to download G-Hub which is the new version of Logitech Gaming Software that these devices use so you can easily manage their features.

Ergonomic preferences are just as subjective as aesthetic preferences, but the wearing of the G432 is enough to make me want to move to more of the more uprange Logitech models (or to another make altogether).
Logitech should be ashamed of themselves.
If it wasnt for the G430 (and all other logitech DJ-style headphones) breaking for anyone that has an even remotely wide head, I would have really liked the G430.

I already had a logitech keyboard and mouse and just made sense to have all three controlled by same app.

* Mic is on a boom that swings up and automatically shuts it off.

Microphone works well, and I have no issues with clarity.

I would pay $15 dollars for this mike.

Had to update audio drivers for mic to work properly.
The downside of the isolation is that it shines a spotlight on less than great drivers.
So there is no separate in-line volume control or in-line micophone mute on/off switch and the mic is flip to mute so it automatically mutes when you raise it up.
One that has the split mic/audio 3.5mm jacks or a USB connection.
The microphone for the G432 is the same as the G430, its middling performance and ok to use if all you are going to do is use it for in-game or VoIP communication with other players.
Although the mute thing is kinda confusing.
Love the mute function on the mike - lift the arm to mute.
I like the automatic hardware mute when flipping up the mic but not sure I prefer it over the in-line dongle mute on the G430.
Only issue with these is that they dont always connect thr microphone to my PS4 through the controller.
They dont cancel out other noises very well but that may be because the mic itself plays to you what it hears.
Only real complaint is that the mic will stay on when flipped up more often then not.
Only a bit disappointed that the mute function on the mic doesn't work perfectly, if you are loud enough it will still pick it up even if it's in the mute position.
The mic really handy in that is shuts off when in the up position and turns back on when lowered.

gaming, music, etc.).
However, in games where the sounds are a lot less isolated in the mix, it was a lot less convincing.
FWIW, I don't think that issue is really a G432-specific problem, unless the driver accuracy affects the DTS:X rendition quite a lot.
Not recommended
As for the sonic performance of the headphones, it was a bit of a mixed bag.
I did record some audio from the mic, and it seemed decent.
For me, the most important things with a gaming headset are sustained comfort, sound quality, and features - in that order.
I don't really use a mic in my gaming, but I do appreciate the flip to mute feature.
You won't miss the response on the top end, but you will on the bottom.
I prefer the sound from closed back, over-the-ear headphones, rather than in ear or on-the-ear units, because of the sound isolation.
So, here we get to DTS:X surround.
First, I find it silly that any sound source with two drivers is being marketed with "7.1" in it.
DTS:X Headphone is a downmixing technique that incorporates a psychoacoustic model to take the discrete channel surround information, and output it to 2-channel headphones.
Even though the frequency response is listed as 20hz to 20khz, the flat(ish) range is more like 140hz to 10khz.
More or less it tricks the brain into thinking there's more spatial information in the audio than there was to begin with.
It does this with delay, shift, phasing and other auditory transformations.
As far as that's concerned, I don't know if there's any difference in just downloading DTS Sound Unbound for free in the Windows Store, and just using that.
I played some demos to test the spatial audio positioning, since I figured that's the "best case" demonstration of the capabilities.
The lower frequencies that are reproduced are not exactly clean.

review_types.best_review: Writing this review after 2 days of purchasing two other, more expensive and highly reviewed headphones that I KNEW would not be like the ones I purchased here. That's the difference between listening to others advice and simply reading the technical specifications of the manufacturer and knowing EXACTLY how the product is going to perform based on those specs. For $49.99 (plus tax) this is probably one of THE BEST purchases I've made in terms of value-to-quality I've made in a quite some time (this entire computer in 2012 as well as the longevity and outpacing of 95% of what's out there with 5-6 years ahead of it was probably THE best). Prior to today, I was using the Corsair Vengeance 1500 V2 for some 10 years and they finally broke for good. If you try to find them now, they've gone up in price, from between 2-3 time and even 10 times what I paid for them, no lie. They had the best processor for Dolby II, DTS & 2.0/5.1/7.1 Surround and the sound was clean, not muddy, not brash or too bright, and the frequency response was good enough to drop some bass through. For video games, you were hearing people in any direction, 360 degrees around horizontally, 360 degrees around vertical (above and under) as well as panning at any direction. Guy walking in brush and you could pop your head up and know exactly where to aim. Sounds in the distance and oncoming planes, tanks, whatever... and again, you knew at what distance and it only enhanced the visual experience even greater. So I salvaged them for a very long time, even using duct tape to keep them together... but like all good things, they come to a final end. Now the problem was, where was I going to find something that rivaled them and not pay an arm and a leg to do so. First things first and I knew I had to start with at least a 50mm speaker so as to induce the proper bass tones I needed. A frequency response of 20-20,000, (with companies like Sennheiser always advertising 12-44,000Hz, ranges that most studios neither use at either end as they are both inaudible, unusable and could damage 95-99% of the rest of speakers out there). But SNR is important and so at a sensitivity of107 +/-3dB and you're talking a very clean sound coming out of them. Before I even installed their G-Hub software (which enables all of the DTS surround features, as well as graphic equalizers and more) I tested these plugged directly into Windows 7 to listen to the flat response with no EQ. SMILES FROM EAR TO EAR as I didn't hear some muddy, hollow or low level sound that needed to be boosted (with an impedance of 39 Ohms (passive), 5k Ohms (active) why would I?) and then tried it with some EQ shaping and it was brilliant on both passes. At no time did I hear any distortion, crackling, feedback, hum or clashing of frequencies and the EQ I tested on could be configured for 15 or 31 band, with customizable settings on the Hz of each band. Installing the G-Hub software was easy, intuitive and worked without any conflicts (which is usually a finger crossing experience on a Windows 7 for most people... but my machine is lean and clean and free of bloatware or Microsoft's mitts on it). The testing panel for surround sound and with it's own EQ system were again, straightforward and the demo for the surround was excellent in that it lets you shape the sound that sounds best for your ears, per speaker, delay, distance and +/-db levels per individual 7.1 channel. Now, if this sounds like overkill to you, you should know something about me first... I have SUPER sensitive hearing and perfect pitch. So much so that I can pick out and identify sounds that are often inaudible to others. In fact, I had a 7.1 home theater system back some 20 years ago and I noticed that with some DVD Blu-Ray titles, there was a terrible popping sound, sounding more like the sound of "Ffffffttt" and only when the scenes were loud, action packed and kicking in the DTS surround or similar. It wasn't on every title, but enough that I noticed it throughout many titles. I brought the main unit to a local dealer as it was under warranty yet and they said they couldn't find anything wrong. I hooked it up and sure enough, it was still there. They tried listening again, this time with high quality speakers in a special soundproof room and with equipment that picks up electrical hum and other sound phenomena. The guy calls me up from the shop and says, "Sir, you must have ears like a dog because we hooked this thing up and every, single scene you said you noticed the problem, our ears in the shop couldn't hear it, but our equipment probes picked it up exactly." (I had written down scenes with times at where I heard the problem and was correct on all of them). He then laughed and said, "Would you like a job? Not for nothing, but I'd hate to have your sense of hearing, it must be annoying". Like you have no idea. Anyway, all I can say is, if you are looking for gaming headphones that can also handle sound AND, ones that aren't made for tiny heads or for teenagers and kids the same, these things expand quite a bit and don't make you feel like a vice clamp is on the sides of your head. The sound quality is superb and the value again, is what we all need in a product like this. Good luck on your future purchases!
review_types.worst_review: Got this on sale at a big box store thinking it was a sweet deal for a 7.1 surround gaming headset, now I see why it was such a deal. At best it's virtual 5.1, needs usb dongle to even activate surround sound, and it really doesn't sound that great for a headset with a $80 list price. There is so much BASS it's stupid. even quiet sounds will rattle your brain. Turned virtual sub to lowest setting and it's still way too much and overpowers everything. And if the BASS won't give you a headache, the clamping force will. If you headbang, they stay put nicely, but quickly turn your head and they will shift. Not comfortable at all for more than a few minutes. And you would think all that clamp force would mean decent sound isolation, but NO! There is virtually none. Even my open back Sennheisers have better noise isolation than these. These are more equivalent to on ear headphones, ridiculous! If you are looking for surround sound headphones or gaming headset, stay away from this. Even if they were free, I would not pickup another pair. Never even tested the mic as I was so disappointed in the sound quality and surround sound, I went back to my regular headphones. Really disappointed in Logitech with this one.
